summary: A series of U.S. Marshals Service investigation reports concerning Jeffrey Epstein's compliance with sex offender travel reporting requirements under International Megan's Law. The reports detail witness interviews, investigative steps, and the eventual closure of the case following Epstein's death by suicide in August 2019.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.role: Convicted sex offender, subject of investigation
persons.context: The primary subject of the U.S. Marshals investigation for potential failure to report international travel as required by International Megan's Law. He was observed with young girls at an airport.

persons.name: Senior Inspector (SI)
persons.role: U.S. Marshals Senior Inspector conducting the investigation
persons.context: Conducted witness interviews, coordinated with the AUSA's office, and submitted investigative requests related to Epstein's travel.

persons.name: Supervisory Inspector (SI)
persons.context: Met with a Miami Herald reporter to gather information on potential witnesses regarding Epstein.

persons.name: Miami Herald Reporter
persons.context: Met with Marshals investigators and provided information about potential informants who had witnessed Epstein with young girls and other individuals with knowledge of his activities.

persons.name: Air Traffic Controller
persons.context: Interviewed by the Senior Inspector. Reported observing Epstein disembark from his plane at an airport with young girls on multiple occasions between June/July and November 2018.

persons.name: AUSA
persons.context: The prosecutor's office in the U.S. Virgin Islands that the Marshals coordinated with on the investigation and MLAT requests. Agreed to drop the case after Epstein's death.

connections.description: The Senior Inspector conducted a phone interview with the air traffic controller to gather information about observing Epstein with young girls.
The Supervisory Inspector met with the reporter at a diner to obtain leads on informants and witnesses related to Epstein.
The Senior Inspector spoke with the AUSA's office regarding the case, submitting MLAT requests, and ultimately closing the investigation.
The reporter provided the air traffic controller's phone number to the Marshals, stating the controller was her informant.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Conviction
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted in Florida of procuring a person under the age of 18 for prostitution and sentenced to 13 months incarceration, requiring lifetime sex offender registration.

events.title: Epstein Reports Travel in USVI
events.description: Epstein visited the US Virgin Islands Department of Justice on St. Thomas and signed a Notification of Duty to Report travel with the Sex Offender Registry Coordinator.

events.title: Reported Travel to France
events.description: Epstein notified authorities of travel to France via his private jet (N212JE), but flight tracking showed additional trips to Vienna, Austria and Monaco that were not reported.

events.title: Interview with Miami Herald Reporter
events.description: U.S. Marshals met with a Miami Herald reporter who provided leads on informants, including an air traffic controller who saw Epstein with girls and a former employee of Epstein.

events.title: Interview with Air Traffic Controller
events.description: A Senior Inspector interviewed an air traffic controller who reported seeing Epstein get off his plane with young girls on multiple occasions in 2018.

events.title: Epstein's Death by Suicide
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein committed suicide while in custody in New York.

events.title: Case Closure Decision
events.description: Following Epstein's death, the U.S. Marshals Senior Inspector spoke with the USVI AUSA's office and all parties agreed to drop the case, canceling all warrants and investigative activities.

locations: Hollywood, Florida (location of interview at Don ite Diner)
keyFacts: The U.S. Marshals were investigating Jeffrey Epstein for potential violations of International Megan's Law related to his failure to report all international travel as a registered sex offender.

A key witness, an air traffic controller, reported observing Epstein disembark from his private plane at an airport with young girls, including some who appeared to be 11-12 years old, on multiple occasions in 2018.
Flight tracking data revealed Epstein traveled to Vienna, Austria and Monaco in March 2019, countries he did not list on his official travel notification form which only listed France.
The investigation was actively pursuing MLAT requests, a search warrant for Epstein's phone, and flight logs to determine the full extent of his unreported travel.
The entire investigation was closed and all pending warrants/requests were canceled on August 12, 2019, following Epstein's death by suicide on August 10, 2019.
